pyttn.oqs.bosonic_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.bosonic_bath.BosonicBath(Jw, S=None, beta=None, wmax=inf, wmin=None)[source]

Bases: object

A class for managing a continuous bosonic gaussian bath. This provides functions for computing non-interacting bath correlation functions, as well as decomposing the correlation function into a linear combination of complex valued exponentials (expfit) or oscillator terms (discretise)

Parameters:

  • Jw – The bath spectral function defining the non-interacting correlation function

  • S (SOP, optional) – The system operator

  • beta (float, optional) – The inverse temperature of the bath, defaults to None

  • wmax (float, optional) – the maximum frequency bound, defaults to np.inf

  • wmin (float, optional) – the minimum frequency bound, defaults to None

Ct(t, epsabs=1.49e-12, epsrel=1.49e-12, limit=2000, epsomega=1e-06)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t, defined by:

\[C(t) = \frac{1}{\pi}\int_{\omega_{\mathrm{min}}}^{\omega_{\mathrm{max}}} J(\omega) f_B(\beta\omega) \exp(- i \omega t)\]
Parameters:

  • t (np.ndarray) – time

  • epsabs (float or int, optional) – absolute error tolerance. (Default: 1.49e-12)

  • epsrel (float or int, optional) – relative error tolerance. (Default: 1.49e-12)

  • limit (float or int, optional) – Upper bound on the number of subintervals used in the integration scheme used to evaluate the correlation function. (Default: 2000)

  • epsomega (float or int, optional) – A bound used to split the integral to avoid singularities at zero that may occur due to the bose function. (Default: 1e-6)

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Ctexp(dk, zk)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t using the results of discretisation or expfit:

Parameters:

  • t (np.ndarray) – time

  • dk (np.ndarray) – the weights of each term in the fit

  • zk (np.ndarray) – the (complex) frequencies of each term in the fit

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Sw(w)[source]

Returns the non-interacting bath spectral function at w

Parameters:

w (np.ndarray) – frequency

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

discretise(discretisation_engine)[source]

Returns the coupling constants and frequencies associated with a discretised representation of the bath

Parameters:

discretisation_engine (np.ndarray) – An object defining how to discretise a continuous bath

Returns:

Discrete system bath coupling constants \(g_k`and bath frequencies :math:\)omega_k`

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

estimate_bounds(wmax=None)[source]

Returns estimates for the upper and lower bounds of the spectral density to be used for the discretisation function

Parameters:

wmax (float, optional) – the maximum frequency bound, defaults to self.wmax

Returns:

the maximum and minimum frequency bounds

Return type:

float, float

expfit(fitting_engine)[source]

Returns the coefficients and decay rates associated with a sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

Parameters:

fitting_engine (np.ndarray) – An object defining how to decompose a correlation function for a continuous bath into a sum-of-exponential decomposition

Returns:

Discrete system bath coupling constants \(g_k\) and bath frequencies \(\omega_k\)

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

find_wmin(wmax, npoints=1000)[source]

Computes an estimate of the minimum frequency used for discretising a bath. Here this is done by taking the maximum frequency and finding the largest value in the range from [-wmax, 0] that has the same spectral weight as the upper bound.

Parameters:

wmax (float, optional) – the maximum frequency bound, defaults to self.wmax

Returns:

the maximum and minimum frequency bounds

Return type:

float, float

pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitBosonicBath(dk, zk, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: ExpFitOQSBath

A class for handling a bosonic bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

__str__()[source]

Return str(self).

add_system_bath_generator(H, Sp, Sm=None, method='heom', binds=None, bskip=2)[source]

Attach the bath and system bath coupling Generators associated with this bath object to an existing SOP Generator

Parameters:

  • H (SOP) – The total Generator

  • Sp (list[sOP or sPOP or sNBO or sSOP]) – A list containing the left and right acting operators that couples to the bath annihilation operator terms

  • Sm (list[sOP or sPOP or sNBO or sSOP, optional]) – A list containing the left and right operator that couples to the bath creation operator terms. If set to None then, we consider coupling of the form Sp(a^dagger + a) (Default: None)

  • method ({"heom", "pseudomode"}) – The method used to represent the bath.

  • binds (list, optional) – A list containing the indices of the bath modes. If this is set to None, the bath modes will be placed in a contiguous block starting at index bskip (Default: None)

  • bskip (int, optional) – The index to start the contiguous block of bath indices. This object is ignored if the binds parameter is specified. (Default: 1)

Returns:

The total Generator now including the system bath terms

Return type:

type(H)

system_bath_generator(Sp, Sm=None, method='heom', binds=None, bskip=2)[source]

Construct a sSOP containing the system bath Generator of the object.

Parameters:

  • H (SOP) – The total Generator

  • Sp (list[sOP or sPOP or sNBO or sSOP]) – A list containing the left and right acting operators that couples to the bath annihilation operator terms

  • Sm (list[sOP or sPOP or sNBO or sSOP, optional]) – A list containing the left and right operator that couples to the bath creation operator terms. If set to None then, we consider coupling of the form Sp(a^dagger + a) (Default: None)

  • method ({"heom", "pseudomode"}) – The method used to represent the bath.

  • binds (list, optional) – A list containing the indices of the bath modes. If this is set to None, the bath modes will be placed in a contiguous block starting at index bskip (Default: None)

  • bskip (int, optional) – The index to start the contiguous block of bath indices. This object is ignored if the binds parameter is specified. (Default: 1)

Returns:

The total Generator now including the system bath terms

Return type:

sSOP

system_information(mode_comb=None, force_evaluate=False)[source]

Constructs and returns a system_modes object suitable for handling the bath degrees of freedom described by this object.

Parameters:

  • mode_comb (ModeCombination, optional) – A mode combination object to apply to the system information class. (Default: None)

  • force_evaluate – Forces evaluation of the system_modes object regardless of whether or not one has already been formed. (Default: False)

Returns:

Bath system information

Return type:

system_modes

truncate_modes(truncation=<pyttn.utils.truncate.DepthTruncation object>)[source]

Determines the local Hilbert space dimension (stored in mode_dims) of each of the bosonic bath modes using the truncation rule defined in the truncation object.

Parameters:

truncation (TruncationBase, optional) – The truncation rule used to determine the potentially frequency and coupling strength dependent local Hilbert space dimension for each mode in the bath. (Default DepthTruncation(8))

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitFermionicBath(dk, zk, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: ExpFitOQSBath

A class for handling a fermionic bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

Attach the bath and system bath coupling Generators associated with this bath object to an existing SOP Generator

  • Sm (list[sOP or sPOP or sNBO or sSOP, optional]) – A list containing the left and right operator that couples to the bath creation operator terms. If set to None then, we consider coupling of the form Sp(a^dagger + a) (Default: None)

  • method ({"heom", "pseudomode"}) – The method used to represent the bath.

  • binds (list, optional) – A list containing the indices of the bath modes. If this is set to None, the bath modes will be placed in a contiguous block starting at index bskip (Default: None)

truncate_modes(truncation=<pyttn.utils.truncate.DepthTruncation object>)[source]

Determines the local Hilbert space dimension (stored in mode_dims) of each of the bosonic bath modes using the truncation rule defined in the truncation object.

Parameters:

truncation (TruncationBase, optional) – The truncation rule used to determine the potentially frequency and coupling strength dependent local Hilbert space dimension for each mode in the bath. (Default DepthTruncation(2))

class pyttn.oqs.exponential_fit_bath.ExpFitOQSBath(dk, zk, fermionic=False, combine_real=False, tol=1e-12)[source]

Bases: object

The base class for handling a bath representing an exponential fit to a bath correlation function of the form

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

  • dk (np.ndarray) – The coefficient in the exponential decomposition

  • zk (np.ndarray) – The decay rates in the exponential decomposition

  • fermionic (bool, optional) – Whether or not the bath is a fermionic bath (default False)

  • combine_real (bool, optional) – Whether or not to combine real frequency modes (default False)

  • tol (float, optional) – The tolerance used to determine if a mode is a real frequency mode (default 1e-12)

Ct(t)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t, defined by:

\[C(t) = \sum_k d_{k} \exp(-z_k t)\]
Parameters:

t (np.ndarray) – time

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

add_bath_tree(node, degree, chi, lhd=None)[source]

Append a tree as a child of node that represents the modes represented by this expfit bath object.

Parameters:

  • node (ntreeNode) – The node where the subtree should be added

  • degree (int) – The degree of the tree. If degree = 1 this appends an MPS subtree otherwise it adds a balanced degree-ary tree.

  • chi (int, list[int], (callable(int))) – The bond dimension to insert throughout the tree. This can accept all types supported by the ntreeBuilder objects

  • lhd (int, list[int], (callable(int)), optional) – The dimension of local Hilbert space transformation nodes. This can accept all types supported by the ntreeBuilder objects. (Default: None)

Returns:

The indices of leaf nodes added to the tree

Return type:

list[list[int]]

property dk

An array containing the bath decomposition coefficients

identity_product_state(method='heom')[source]

Set up arrays necessary to construct the identity state used for trace evaluation with na expfit bath object. For method = “heom”, this corresponds to the vacuum state of the bath For method = “pseudomode”, this corresponds to a flattened identity operator

Parameters:

method ({"heom", "pseudomode"}) – The method used to represent the bath.

Returns:

A list of numpy arrays that are used to set the identity operator for the bath modes.

Return type:

list[np.ndarray]

is_fermionic()[source]

Returns whether or not the bath is fermionic :rtype: bool

property mode_dims

An array containing the dimensionality of each of the modes

property zk

An array containing the bath decomposition decay rates

pyttn.oqs.fermionic_bath module

class pyttn.oqs.fermionic_bath.FermionicBath(Jw, Sp=None, Sm=None, beta=None, wmax=inf, wmin=None, wtol=None)[source]

Bases: object

A class for managing a continuous fermionic gaussian bath. This provides functions for computing non-interacting bath correlation functions, as well as decomposing the correlation function into a linear combination of complex valued exponentials (expfit) or oscillator terms (discretise)

Parameters:

  • Jw – The bath spectral function defining the non-interacting correlation function

  • beta (float, optional) – The inverse temperature of the bath, defaults to None

  • wmax (float, optional) – the maximum frequency bound, default to np.inf

  • wmin (float, optional) – the minimum frequency bound, default to np.inf

  • wtol (float, optional) – a value for determining wmin based on wmax. See fermionic.bath.estimate_bounds, default to None

Ct(t, Ef=0, sigma='+', epsabs=1.49e-12, epsrel=1.49e-12, limit=2000)[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t:

\[C^{\sigma}(t) = \frac{1}{pi}\int_{wmin}^{wmax} J(\omega) f_F(\sigma\beta(\omega - Ef)) exp(\sigma i \omega t)\]
Parameters:

  • t (np.ndarray) – time

  • Ef (float, optional) – The fermi energy, default to 0

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Ctexp(dk, zk, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the value of the non-interacting bath correlation function evaluated at the time points t using the results of discretisation or expfit:

Parameters:

  • t (np.ndarray) – time

  • dk (np.ndarray) – the weights of each term in the fit

  • zk (np.ndarray) – the (complex) frequencies of each term in the fit

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

Sw(w, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the non-interacting bath spectral function at w and fermi energy Ef

\[S^{\sigma}(\omega) = J(\omega) f_{f}(\sigma \omega; \beta)\]
Parameters:

  • w (np.ndarray) – frequency

  • Ef (float) – Fermi Energy

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

The bath correlation function

Return type:

np.ndarray

discretise(discretisation_engine, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the coupling constants and frequencies associated with a discretised representation of the bath

Parameters:

  • discretisation_engine (np.ndarray) – An object defining how to discretise a continuous bath

  • Ef (float) – Fermi Energy

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

Discrete system bath coupling constants \(g_k`and bath frequencies :math:\)omega_k`

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

Returns estimates for the upper and lower bounds of the spectral density to be used for the discretisation function

Parameters:

  • Ef (float) – Fermi Energy

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

the maximum and minimum frequency bounds

Return type:

float, float

expfit(fitting_engine, Ef=0, sigma='+')[source]

Returns the coefficients and decay rates associated with a sum-of-exponential decomposition of the bath correlation function

Parameters:

  • fitting_engine (np.ndarray) – An object defining how to decompose a correlation function for a continuous bath into a sum-of-exponential decomposition

  • Ef (float) – Fermi Energy

  • sigma (str, optional) – Whether to compute the spectral function associated with the greater (+) or lesser (-) Green’s Function, default to +

Returns:

Discrete system bath coupling constants \(g_k`and bath frequencies :math:\)omega_k`

Return type:

np.ndarray, np.ndarray

  • Ef (float) – Fermi Energy
